questions.text: When should an elective caesarean section ideally be performed?
questions.solution:
An elective caesarean section should ideally be performed after 39 weeks.

It is not done before 39 weeks of gestation as there is an increased risk of:

  • Complications related to prematurity including respiratory problems 
  • Neonatal adaptation problems such as hypothermia and hypoglycemia

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is set to undergo an elective LSCS 2 days later. What is the ideal time to administer antibiotics to this patient?
questions.solution:
According to ACOG guidelines, the ideal time to administer antibiotics is within a time period of 60 mins prior to the planned caesarean section.

Antimicrobial administration before surgical incision has been shown to lower postoperative infection rates without adverse neonatal effects, as compared with drug administration after umbilical cord clamping. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice.

For emergency delivery, antibiotic prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible.

questions.text: The partogram of a 26-year-old G2P1 woman is shown below. What is the prophylactic antibiotic of choice for this patient before definitive management is done?
questions.solution:
The above partogram is suggestive of obstructed labour and the definitive management in this case is caesarean section. Cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice for antibiotic prophylaxis before caesarean section.

According to the partogram, there is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate indicating fetal distress. Hence, the management plan is to perform a caesarean section.

The recommended prophylactic drug is a single intravenous dose of a β-lactam antimicrobial. This could either be a cephalosporin or an extended-spectrum penicillin derivative. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is usually given. For obese women, a 2 g dose is better to provide an adequate coverage.

questions.text: You are asked to administer antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis to a patient posted for elective LSCS. What condition does the patient likely have?
questions.solution:
Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis before surgical procedures is recommended in patients with prosthetic valves, prior history of endocarditis, and unrepaired cyanotic heart diseases.

Pregnant women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease, prosthetic valves, or both. However, endocarditis prophylaxis is not required if the patient is already receiving intrapartum prophylaxis with broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent endometritis. 

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for atrial septal defect (ASD). The risk of endocarditis with ASD is negligible. Bacterial endocarditis is associated with unrepaired ventricular septal defects where antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended. Similarly, prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis is indicated at delivery for unrepaired patent ductus arteriosus.

 

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese pregnant woman is scheduled for caesarean section. While going through her file, you find that she is allergic to penicillin. What is/are the antibiotic(s) you would prescribe for her?
questions.solution:
In an obese pregnant woman who is allergic to penicillin, a dose of 900 mg clindamycin with an aminoglycoside is used for antibiotic prophylaxis.

In women with significant penicillin or cephalosporin allergy, a single 600 mg intravenous dose of clindamycin combined with a weight-based dose of aminoglycoside is recommended. For obese women, a 900 mg dose is preferred.

questions.text: A woman with preeclampsia presents with haemorrhage at 38 weeks of gestation. You decide to perform a caesarean section and terminate the pregnancy. What is the anaesthesia of choice?
questions.solution:
General anaesthesia is the anaesthesia of choice here since the patient presents with haemorrhage.

General anaesthesia may be indicated for emergency cesarean delivery in patients with a reassuring airway examination. It is also recommended for patients with severe coagulopathy where neuraxial anesthesia is contraindicated. 

Spinal anesthesia is not preferred when the operation is expected to result in blood loss or in a previously haemorrhaging patient. It is because in such cases the development of severe hypovolemia is likely which is a contraindication for this type of anaesthesia.

questions.text: An elective cesarean section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected cephalopelvic disproportion.  In which of the following abdominal incisions are the recti muscles transected?
questions.solution:
The recti muscles are transected in the Maylard incision for caesarean delivery which is marked as '2' in the given image. 

It is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.

The various incisions mentioned in the image are:

Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision.

Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.

Incision '4' - Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery. It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. 

This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

questions.text: All of the following are benefits of using a transverse abdominal incision for caesarean delivery in a patient except______.
questions.solution:
Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.

Related Pearl: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: An elective C-section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected contracted pelvis. After opening the abdomen through a modified Pfannenstiel incision, the obstetrician makes a low transverse uterine incision. How should this incision be extended?

choices.text: By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each index finger
By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each index finger
By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each thumb
By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each thumb

questions.solution:
In a C-section, the incision on the uterus can be extended by using lateral and slightly upward pressure applied with each index finger.

If the lower uterine segment is thick, then cutting laterally and then slightly upward with bandage scissors will extend the incision.

Note: When scissors are used, the index and middle fingers of the non-dominant hand should be insinuated between the myometrium and the fetal parts to prevent fetal laceration.

questions.text: The highest risk of uterine rupture is seen with______.
questions.solution:
A T-shaped incision has the highest risk of uterine rupture among the given options. Among all the incisions, a previous classical cesarean incision has the highest risk of rupture but it is not an option here.

Overall, the maximum risk of uterine rupture is in patients who have had a previous upper segment uterine rupture. Women with single prior low-transverse hysterotomy have the lowest risk of symptomatic scar separation.

questions.text: An obstetrician performing a C-section exteriorises the uterus before performing uterine repair. All of the following are true about this procedure except_______.

choices.text: Incision and bleeding points are easily visualized and repaired
Relaxed/atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied
Vomiting and discomfort is caused by traction due to exteriorization
Adnexal exposure is low so tubal sterilization is difficult

questions.solution:
Adnexal exposure is high and hence tubal sterilization is easy.

After delivery of the placenta, the uterus is lifted through the incision onto the draped abdominal wall. The fundus is covered with a moistened laparotomy sponge and this is known as exteriorisation of uterus.

Benefits of exteriorization:

  • Relaxed, atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied.
  • The incision and bleeding points are more easily visualized and repaired.
  • Adnexal exposure is superior, and thus, tubal sterilization is easier.

Drawbacks of exteriorization:

  • Intraoperative nausea and vomiting
  • Need for additional uterotonics
  • Longer time duration to the first recognized bowel movement

The below image shows the exteriorisation of the uterus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy.

Indications for peripartum hysterectomy include:

  • Uterine atony - when every other method fails to control PPH
  • Uterine extension
  • Uterine rupture
  • Postpartum uterine infection
  • Cervical laceration
  • Leiomyoma - large leiomyomas in a woman with completed family
  • Ovarian neoplasia

questions.text: What is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section?
questions.solution:
Skin laceration is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section. Other injuries seen include:

  • Cephalohematoma
  • Brachial plexus injury
  • Clavicular fracture
  • Skull fracture
  • Facial nerve palsy

questions.text: An elective caesarean section is planned for a pregnant woman with a cardiac ailment. Which of the following complications is she not at an increased risk for?
questions.solution:
Elective caesarean section decreases the risk of chorioamnionitis.

Maternal complications increase with caesarean section when compared with vaginal deliveries. Some of these complications include: 

  • Post-operative infection
  • Haemorrhage
  • Thromboembolism
  • Anaesthesia-related complications
  • Mendelson syndrome/ aspiration pneumonitis

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below?

A. It is used in women not on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
B. It is used in women on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
C. It is removed once the patient starts ambulating.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pneumatic compression device. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for cesarean section (statement A) and it is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery (statement C).

The device is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.

According to recent guidelines, patients with no additional risk factors and not placed on any pharmacological thromboprophylaxis are placed on pneumatic compression devices before cesarean delivery. Patients undergoing cesarean delivery with additional risk factors are put on both pneumatic compression devices and pharmacological therapy (UFH or LMWH). UFH-unfractionated heparin, LMWH-lower molecular weight heparin.

Indications of pharmacological thromboprophylaxis:

  • Inherited coagulation disorder
  • Overweight or obese patient
  • Heart failure
  • Family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism

questions.text: The risk factors for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section include all except______.
questions.solution:
Age >35 years is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section. The other risk factors include:

  • Emergency cesarean
  • Obesity
  • Parity >3
  • Caesarean hysterectomy
  • Concurrent infection
  • Preeclampsia
  • Prior deep-vein thrombosis or thrombophilia

questions.text: A 28-year-old multigravida with a history of C-section is being considered for vaginal delivery. The presence of which of the following features would categorise this procedure as low risk?
questions.solution:
Transverse incision in prior caesarean section is a low risk factor in vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC).

Risk factors for VBAC:

High risk -

  • Classical or T-incision in prior cesarean
  • Prior rupture
  • Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa
  • Inadequate facilities

Low risk -

  • Transverse incision in prior cesarean
  • Prior vaginal delivery
  • Sufficient personnel and equipment

questions.text: A trial of scar is performed on a G2P1L1 woman. The risk of which of the following complications is increased in this baby when compared to their elder sibling?
questions.solution:
Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in neonates has a higher incidence with trial of scar or VBAC as compared to elective cesarean. 

Uterine rupture is a dangerous complication of VBAC. This leads to hemorrhage which can cause the baby to be hypoxic eventually leading to permanent brain damage from hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. This results in developmental delay and cerebral palsy.

Birth trauma, transient tachypnea of newborn (TTN) and neonatal sepsis are more commonly seen with elective caesarean in comparison to VBAC.
